description:
DTU develops technology for people. With our international elite research and study programmes, we are helping to create a better world and to solve the global challenges formulated in the UN’s 17 Sustainable Development Goals.

Hans Christian Ørsted founded DTU in 1829 with a clear vision to develop and create value using science and engineering to benefit society. That vision lives on today. 

"Follow" us on LinkedIn and receive relevant news from an organisation in progress.

Privacy policy: https://www.dtu.dk/english/about/strategy-policy/policies/privacy-policy

Moderation: We reserve the right to delete comments that are offensive or suggestive, personal attacks, anonymous, wildly off-topic, spam or advertisements.

updates.text:
Throughout her working life, Professor Daniela Pigosso has realized that sustainable innovations can end up increasing the environmental impact if changes in consumer behaviour are not considered. Now, she has received the Grundfoss Prize 2024 for her work on Design for Sustainability - awarded by Grundfos Foundation | PDJF.

“If we are to succeed in the green transition, it is not enough that the intentions are good. The potential sustainability benefits of new innovations can only be realized if rebound effects are taken into account,” says Daniela. 

Read more about her work here https://l.dtu.dk/3YB27xB
Læs mere om hendes arbejde https://l.dtu.dk/3YEYR4c

#DTUdk #TechnologyForPeople #Engineering #Sustainability #Innovation

Meltwater's path from the top of Greenland's ice sheet to the ocean is now mapped. 

Meltwater lakes on the surface of the Greenland ice sheet are growing larger due to climate changes. In fact, Greenland loses about five cubic kilometres of ice each week - equivalent to five ice blocks measuring 1x1x1 kilometres - making it the single greatest contributor to the rise of the global sea level. 

𝗟𝗶𝗺𝗶𝘁𝗲𝗱 𝗸𝗻𝗼𝘄𝗹𝗲𝗱𝗴𝗲
Until now, there has been limited knowledge about how meltwater affects ice movement and sea level rise when it disappears from the lakes on the surface of the ice sheet. 

However, this has now been illuminated by new research which was recently published in the scientific journal Nature.

"It has been unclear what happens to meltwater from the surface of Greenland's ice sheet when it flows beneath the ice and into the Arctic Ocean, a process that is increasing as Greenland warms. So far, we have not been able to map these processes, but now we can,” says Professor, Shfaqat Abbas Khan.

𝗚𝗣𝗦 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗚𝗹𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗹 𝗡𝗮𝘃𝗶𝗴𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗦𝗮𝘁𝗲𝗹𝗹𝗶𝘁𝗲 𝗦𝘆𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗺
The measurements were made using GNET in Greenland. GNET is a series of observation stations based on the Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS). 

Using GPS, the GNET stations measure the up-and-down movements of Greenland's bedrock as the ice and water above it change shape and position. 

In the end, this allows the movement of water flows to be determined.

Read more https://l.dtu.dk/4frz06O
Læs mere https://l.dtu.dk/3YxQxU5

#DTUdk #TechnologyForPeople #Engineering #Sustainability #Climatechange #Greenland #SDGs2030

💫 New research in our Milky Way has revealed a neutron star that rotates around its axis at an extremely high speed. It spins 716 times per second, making it one of the fastest-spinning objects ever observed.

The neutron star was observed using NASA's NICER X-ray telescope, which is mounted on the International Space Station and equipped with star-tracker technology from DTU. The researchers were looking at the Sagittarius constellation towards the centre of our galaxy.

"We were studying thermonuclear explosions from this system and then found remarkable oscillations, suggesting a neutron star spinning around its centre axis at an astounding 716 times per second," says Senior Scientist Dr Gaurava Jaisawal.

Gaurava Jaisawal is part of an international team of researchers behind the new finding and the first author of an article about it that was just published in the renowned Astrophysical Journal:

"If future observations confirm this, the 4U 1820-30 neutron star would be one of the fastest-spinning objects ever observed in the universe, matched only by another neutron star called PSR J1748–2446".

Read more https://l.dtu.dk/3YvgYtx
Læs mere https://l.dtu.dk/3YLuXfT

Photo: NASA - National Aeronautics and Space Administration 

#DTUdk #TechnologyForPeople #Engineering #SpaceTech #SpaceTechnology #SpaceExploration #NASA

How can plants grow despite drought and high soil salinity?
 
Researchers behind the DTU startup Agrobiomics have found a group of beneficial bacteria that produce an organic acid that helps boost plants' photosynthesis and regulate various stress reactions in the plants. This enables the plants to grow despite drought and high soil salinity.
 
The organic acid is extracted from fermentation with the beneficial bacteria and used to coat seeds, making future crops more resistant to salt and drought.
 
"We want to create an alternative that is good for the environment and, therefore, public health in the long term. That's why we use nature's own resources, such as natural microbes that can contribute to plant growth. We have found soil bacteria that produce an active substance that helps plants cope with different types of abiotic stress," says Ling Ding, associate professor at DTU and co-founder of Agrobiomics.
 
After promising results in greenhouses, Agrobiomics is now conducting tests in field conditions with tomatoes and soybeans in saline soils and/or prone to drought in Spain and Brazil.
 
Read more about Ling Ding and Agrobiomics:
 
In English: https://l.dtu.dk/406OAQO 
På Dansk: https://l.dtu.dk/4fdPZsW 

#DTUdk #TechnologyForPeople #Engineering #Innovation #Sustainability #Agriculture

With a solid 25 million injection into the deep-tech fund, PSV Hafnium, the Danish Society of Engineers, IDA is backing investments in early-stage deep-tech entrepreneurs. This brings the fund to a total of DKK 410 million.

According to IDA President Laura Klitgaard, investing millions in the Nordic-focused venture fund will help strengthen the development of the STEM field's innovative power, which is crucial to the fund's success and Denmark securing its position of strength in deep tech. 

DTU’s President Anders Overgaard Bjarklev is in favour of IDA moving closer:

“We have great innovative power in Denmark, but we must ensure a well-functioning market for risk capital from private investors, venture and private equity funds and public actors,” he says. 

"Therefore, it is great that IDA invests in PSV Hafnium and recognizes the need to strengthen innovation ecosystems. DTU's vision is that through research and innovation, we solve global challenges for the benefit of society. This requires, among other things, that we convert research into businesses."

As PSV Hafnium was born out of the venture house PSV, which is and has been based at DTU for the past 20 years, the foundation is uniquely positioned to bridge the gap between research and the commercial journey.

Read more https://l.dtu.dk/3YL2ff3
Læs mere https://l.dtu.dk/4hq1O17

#DTUdk #TechnologyForPeople #Engineering #Entrepreneurship #Startup #Sustainability #Innovation #deeptech  #PSVventurehus #PSVHafnium

High quality in research, education and innovation has earned DTU the status as the best technical university in the EU.

"It is a great pleasure that DTU is at the very top. First place in EngiRank is the result of a shared focus on delivering world-class research, education and innovation. The result is due to the impressive work of students, staff and partners," says President Anders Overgaard Bjarklev.

Engirank - European Ranking of Engineering Programs assesses 226 technical universities in 27 EU countries, Switzerland and Norway. The ranking is based on a broad selection of recognized EU data sources.

EngiRank's primary criteria are research, innovation, teaching quality and universities' work with the UN Sustainable Development Goals. In addition, it operates with seven subject rankings.

This is the second time EngiRank has ranked technical universities in the EU and the second time DTU has been recognized as the best university. 

Read more about how DTU ranks in the seven subject rankings and find a link to the EngiRank 2024 here:

In English https://l.dtu.dk/4e3qWYH
På dansk https://l.dtu.dk/3YHfNIE

#DTUdk #TechnologyForPeople #Engineering #Sustainability #Innovation #DigitalTransformation #SDG9 #Ranking

If Europe is not to fall behind in the global technology race, it must invest heavily in research and development.

This message has recently been repeated by both European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen and former European Central Bank President Mario Draghi.

The same message comes from President Anders Overgaard Bjarklev and the other 14 members of an expert group that on Wednesday presented its recommendations on how the EU should structure its research policy. Not least when it comes to the important Horizon Europe programme, which has an annual budget of more than 15 billion euros.

The expert group points to 𝟭𝟮 𝗰𝗼𝗻𝗰𝗿𝗲𝘁𝗲 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝘀𝘂𝗿𝗲𝘀 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗰𝗮𝗻 𝗵𝗲𝗹𝗽 𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗴𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗻 𝗰𝗼𝗺𝗽𝗲𝘁𝗶𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲𝗻𝗲𝘀𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝗘𝘂𝗿𝗼𝗽𝗲. To succeed, we need an ambitious policy that manages to combine research and business, says President Anders Bjarklev.

Find the link to the full expert group report and recommendations here:

Read more https://l.dtu.dk/40fifaA
Læs mere https://l.dtu.dk/48ng6eP

#DTUdk #TechnologyForPeople #Engineering #Innovation #DigitalTransformation #Technology #Horizon2020

You may never have heard of Professor Sune Lehmann, but chances are you have heard of his research. Research that makes headlines - globally. Can you recognise some of these? 

• At the end of 2023, he and other Danish and international research colleagues published a new AI algorithm that can 𝗽𝗿𝗲𝗱𝗶𝗰𝘁 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗻𝘁𝘀 𝗶𝗻 𝗮 𝗽𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗼𝗻’𝘀 𝗹𝗶𝗳𝗲 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗲𝘀𝘁𝗶𝗺𝗮𝘁𝗲 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗽𝗿𝗼𝗯𝗮𝗯𝗹𝗲 𝘁𝗶𝗺𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝗱𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗵.

• During the pandemic, he was part of the large award-winning Danish research team HOPE, which was able to 𝗱𝗲𝗱𝘂𝗰𝗲 𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝗱𝗶𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗹𝗼𝗰𝗸𝗱𝗼𝘄𝗻 𝗺𝗲𝗮𝘀𝘂𝗿𝗲𝘀 𝘄𝗼𝘂𝗹𝗱 𝗮𝗳𝗳𝗲𝗰𝘁 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝘀𝗽𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗱 𝗼𝗳 𝗶𝗻𝗳𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻, done through analyses of citizens’ behaviour.

• When in 2019, together with international colleagues, he was able to demonstrate that 𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝗰𝗼𝗹𝗹𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲 𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝘄𝗼𝗿𝗹𝗱𝘄𝗶𝗱𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗱𝗲𝗰𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝗻 𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗽 𝘄𝗶𝘁𝗵 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗿𝗮𝗽𝗶𝗱𝗹𝘆 𝗮𝗰𝗰𝗲𝗹𝗲𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗶𝗻𝗰𝗿𝗲𝗮𝘀𝗲 𝗶𝗻 𝗻𝗲𝘄𝘀, 𝗮𝗴𝗲𝗻𝗱𝗮𝘀, 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝘁𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗱𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗵𝗮𝘀𝗵𝘁𝗮𝗴𝘀.

So, how does a professor, time and again, end up behind some of the most eye-catching discoveries?

Meet Sune Lehmann, a physicist that explores people’s lives and behaviour through data from social media and statistics 👇

Read more https://l.dtu.dk/48nbDZB
Læs mere https://l.dtu.dk/3YvvLFD

#DTUdk #TechnologyForPeople #Engineering #Innovation #DataScience #Research

A DTU research project is among the first projects that the Novo Nordisk Foundation and the Danish Centre for AI Innovation (DCAI), have selected to gain access to the AI supercomputer ‘Gefion’. The project will map the dynamics of enzymes and develop enzymes that can convert CO2 into sustainable fuels and chemicals.

The fact that DTU is one of the first universities to gain access to the supercomputer emphasizes the university's vision of making a positive difference to society and the green transition, states Christine Nellemann, Dean of Sustainability, Diversity, Inclusion and International Collaborations at DTU.

In the future, using enzymes to convert captured CO2 could be a sustainable and efficient supplement to the man-made power-to-X processes we use today.

"Access to Gefion will allow us to study a class of very interesting enzymes that can convert CO2 into sustainable fuels and chemicals. This can be done with unprecedented accuracy and speed, allowing us to identify new, efficient enzymes for converting CO2 into sustainable fuels such as methanol," says DTU Professor Tejs Vegge and Director of the Pioneer Center CAPeX.

Read more https://l.dtu.dk/3zYBNp2
Læs mere https://l.dtu.dk/3YkE59N

Photo: Novo Nordisk Foundation

#DTUdk #TechnologyForPeople #Engineering #Sustainability #Innovation #DigitalTransformation #ArtificialIntelligence #GreenTransformation

This week, DTU got a new test facility—Risø Hybrid Power Plant. 

"Research is one of the most important keys to the green transition. Risø Hybrid Power Plant will help us develop the right technological solutions and make them scalable. It’s a test facility that will make a noticeable difference in the work of converting the energy system to 100 per cent renewable energy," says President Anders Overgaard Bjarklev. 

The Risø Hybrid Power Plant has: 
• two wind turbines
• a solar power plant
• an attached battery

It is a small facility that can only produce electricity for the annual consumption of 200 households. 

The purpose of the plant is to develop and test new technologies before scaling them up to commercial full-scale hybrid power plants. Plants that will potentially supply several hundred thousand households.

At the inauguration of the Risø Hybrid Power Plant, built in collaboration with the energy company TotalEnergies, Lars Aagaard (The Ministry of Climate, Energy and Utilities) and Marie-Noëlle Semeria , Senior Vice President R&D OneTech participated. 


Read more https://l.dtu.dk/4dWkwKZ
Læs mere https://l.dtu.dk/3UeH2I4

Drone video by Andreas Bro

#DTUdk #TechnologyForPeople #Engineering #Sustainability #Innovation #renewableenergy #energytransition #sustainability #grønenergi #bæredygtighed #DTEC
